history.content:
For the past spring semester, Stat 135 used Mathematical Statistics and Data Analysis by Rice, in addition to a few linear regression topics which were beyond the scope of the book (I used notes from lectures and also consulted notes from https://www.stat.cmu.edu/~cshalizi/mreg/15/ to supplement some missing gaps for those lectures).

On a side note, I personally didn't like some parts of the book because a lot of it were very abstract, and even though I was able to follow the math, the book did not explain the intuition or the subtle differences between various statistical methods. I would recommend reading through Wikipedia articles or checking out other online materials if the same applies to you!

children.subject:
The Rice book was a nice overview to have theorems/flowcharts (like depending on your situation do you want to use a parametric or non parametric test, z test or t test etc), but like the student answer I found the proofs really hard to follow. 

Prof. Lucas who regularly teaches 135 made youtube video summaries of his lectures. Here's a link to lec1 of fall18 - I think the other lectures should be visible from there. Check them out and see if they're helpful to you - disclaimer I have not watched any myself but wanted to provide the resource just in case.
Here's an online MOOC with similar materials taught by MIT: https://www.edx.org/course/fundamentals-of-statistics

history.content:
Hi! I found that I have no room for stat 135 as a CS major, and I'd like to self-study the materials. Could anyone give me some suggestions? I found the webcast for 135 of spring 2018. Can anyone tell me what textbook is stat 135 using?

Thanks!
history.subject: Ways to self-study stat 135?
